user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_dyn_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_dyn_response (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *url,
                            const char *method,
                            const char *version,
                            const char *upload_data,
                            size_t *upload_data_size,
                            void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function answer_unique_dyn_response:
static char *body_dyn = NULL
...
static size_t body_dyn_size
...
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET "GET"
...
#define MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD "HEAD"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments not listed were evaluated and not considered relevant to MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13. The const-qualified pointer parameters already present in the signature (const char *url, const char *method, const char *version, const char *upload_data) need no further investigation for missing const. The string-literal method macros (e.g. MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET) are used via const char * and are appropriate. The explicit (void) casts marking unused parameters are harmless and do not affect pointer qualification. Many of the function parameter types and callback signature components originate from the external MHD API; those prototype-mandated pointer types (e.g. struct MHD_Connection * and size_t * parameters) cannot be changed locally without breaking the required callback signature, so they are not flagged here. Other non-pointer symbols (e.g. body_dyn_size) are irrelevant to Rule 8.13.
